entry.title: Flood Warning issued November 15 at 7:44PM EST by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.
.River levels on the St Johns at Astor have shown a slight increase over the past 24 hours due to northerly winds, remaining in Moderate Flood stage. Northeast winds behind a cold front will keep the river levels steady into the weekend. The river is then forecast to resume a very slow decline into next week, falling near Minor Flood Stage. Residents and interests along the Saint Johns River should continue to expect prolonged flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Saturday morning at 1030 AM EST.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest to the river on McPherson Lane.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:30 PM EST Friday the stage was 3.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 6:30 PM EST Friday was 3.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 3.2 feet just after midnight tonight. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued November 15 at 8:37PM AST until November 16 at 6:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Life-threatening rip currents due to breaking waves up to 6 feet, occasionally higher.
* WHERE...Beaches of northern Vieques.
* WHEN...Through Saturday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents that can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water where it becomes difficult to return to safety.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 15 at 3:32PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary: A slow moving storm system will continue to bring periods of light to moderate snow to the Anchorage Bowl through Sunday morning. 3 to 6 inches of snow is possible for lower elevations of Anchorage with 5 to 10 inches possible for the Anchorage Hillside and Eagle River. For most locations, the steadier snowfall is likely to fall through Saturday afternoon. The snow will taper off from west to east, with snow showers lingering along the Upper Hillside through Sunday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Anchorage

cap:parameter.value: ONGOING LONG DURATION SNOW EVENT FOR THE ANCHORAGE BOWL THROUGH SUNDAY MORNING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 15 at 3:32PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary: A slow moving storm system to continue to bring periods of light to moderate snow to the Mat-Su Valleys through Sunday morning. 3 to 6 inches of snow is possible for most locations, with the highest snow totals likely around Willow and Palmer. For locations in the Susitna Valley, the steadier snowfall is likely to fall again Saturday morning. For the Matanuska Valley, the steadier snow is likely to fall Saturday morning and again Sunday morning. The snow will taper off from west to east through Sunday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Matanuska Valley; Susitna Valley

cap:parameter.value: ONGOING LONG DURATION SNOW EVENT FOR THE MAT-SU VALLEYS THROUGH SUNDAY MORNING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 15 at 3:32PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary: A slow moving storm system will bring periods of light to moderate snow to the Western Kenai Peninsula Friday morning through Sunday morning. An additional 2 to 6 inches of snow is possible for most locations, with the highest snow totals likely in the Kenai and Soldotna areas. For most locations, the steadier snowfall is likely to fall through Saturday morning. The snow will taper off from west to east, with snow showers possible along the higher terrain into Sunday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Kenai Peninsula

entry.title: Flood Watch issued November 15 at 4:10PM PST until November 17 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...A portion of northwest Washington, including the following county, Mason.
* WHEN...From Saturday evening through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Low-water crossings may be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A storm coming in over the Olympics Saturday will bring 2 to 3 inches of rain with snow levels at times above 5000 feet. With the Skokomish River running high at near 16 feet, this will be enough to drive it above flood stage early Sunday morning. River forecasts are trending higher and the river could exceed moderate stage again. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Mason, WA

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued November 15 at 3:52PM PST until November 16 at 1:00PM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...High astronomical tides will cause minor flooding in low lying areas around Humboldt Bay. Up to one half foot of saltwater inundation above ground level is possible near shorelines and tidal waterways. Between 8.8 and 9.0 feet MLLW at the North Spit tide gauge is predicted.
* WHERE...Northern Humboldt Coast County.
* WHEN...From 10 AM to 1 PM PST Saturday.. High tide is at 11 am at the Humboldt Bay North Spit tide gauge. Saltwater inundation will be possible 1 to 2 hours before and after high tide.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of low lying areas around Humboldt Bay including parks and roads with only isolated closures expected. Flooding will likely impact Jackson Ranch Road in the Arcata Bottoms and several roads in King Salmon.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Humboldt Coast

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued November 15 at 6:45PM EST until November 16 at 11:00AM EST by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Warning, 2 to 4 feet of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 5 to 9 feet in the surf zone.
* WHERE...Ocracoke Island and Hatteras Island.
* WHEN...Until 11 AM EST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Up to 2 to 4 feet of inundation above ground level is possible in some areas near shorelines and tidal waterways resulting in a significant threat to life and property. Severe flooding will extend inland from the waterfront causing potential flooding of some homes and businesses. In some areas, battering waves could cause additional damage to property. Some roads may be impassable under several feet of water and vehicles submerged. Portions of Highway 12 remain closed this afternoon and will remain impacted with ocean overwash in Hatteras and Ocracoke Islands, especially around times of high tide (around 6:40 PM this evening and 7 AM Saturday morning).
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ocracoke Island; Hatteras Island

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued November 15 at 6:15PM EST until November 16 at 6:00PM EST by NWS Albany NY
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IS IN EFFECT FROM 7 AM TO 6 PM EST SATURDAY FOR FOR GUSTY WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR SOUTHERN VERMONT...
The National Weather Service in Albany has issued a Red Flag Warning for critical fire weather conditions, which is in effect from 7 AM to 6 PM EST Saturday.
* Affected Area...All of Bennington and Windham Counties.
* Timing...From 7 AM to 6 PM EST Saturday.
* Winds...Northwest 10 to 15 mph with gusts up to 20 mph.
* Relative Humidity...As low as 25 percent.
* Temperatures...Up to 55.
* Impacts...Unusually dry vegetation combined with gusty winds and low relative humidity will promote the potential for rapid fire spread with any fires that may start.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Taconics; Southern Greens; Lower Connecticut Valley South

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 15 at 6:12PM EST by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
The combination of prolonged dry weather, northwesterly winds up to 20 mph with locally higher gusts, relative humidity values between 25 and 35 percent, and dry fuels will contribute to the potential for rapid fire spread that may start for portions of eastern New York, including the western Champlain Valley, as well as areas from the Green Mountains eastwards.
An emergency statewide burn ban is in effect until November 30th for New York. No burn permits will be issued at this time. Use extra caution if handling any potential ignition sources, such as machinery or matches, and ensure to properly extinguish or dispose cigarette butts. Across Vermont, burn bans remain in effect across Rutland, Windsor, Bennington, and Windham Counties. Consult with local or state fire or forestry officials before any burning. Never leave a campfire unattended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Clinton; Western Clinton; Western Essex; Eastern Essex; Orleans; Essex; Lamoille; Caledonia; Washington; Orange; Western Rutland; Eastern Franklin; Eastern Chittenden; Eastern Addison

cap:parameter.value: ELEVATED RISK FOR FIRE SPREAD SATURDAY

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued November 15 at 6:09PM EST until November 16 at 6:00PM EST by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
...GUSTY WINDS AND DRY CONDITIONS WILL LEAD TO CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS SATURDAY...
.The combination of winds gusting up to 30 mph and dry air with relative humidity values falling into the 20s is expected to create critical fire weather conditions through Saturday. Dead and dry vegetation will combine with these weather conditions, leading to the potential for rapid fire growth.
The National Weather Service in Gray has issued a Red Flag Warning for critical fire weather conditions, which is in effect from 7 AM to 6 PM EST Saturday.
* Affected Area...Fire Weather Zone 024 Lake Sunapee and Monadnocks and Fire Weather Zone 025 Merrimack Valley.
* Timing...Saturday, mainly in the afternoon.
* Winds...Northwest 10 to 15 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.
* Relative Humidity...As low as 20 percent.
* Temperatures...Highs around 55. Lows around 30.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued November 15 at 6:05PM EST until November 16 at 6:00PM EST by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 7 AM TO 6 PM EST SATURDAY FOR GUSTY WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR THE SOUTH CENTRAL GREEN MOUNTAIN REGION AND THE LOWER CONNECTICUT RIVER VALLEY...
The National Weather Service in Burlington has issued a Red Flag Warning which is in effect from 7 AM to 6 PM EST Saturday.
* AFFECTED AREA...Portions of southern Vermont
* Timing...From 7 AM Saturday until 6 PM. The strongest winds and lowest relative humidity values will occur between 9 AM and 3 PM.
* WINDS...Northwest 10 to 15 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 25 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Up to 50.
* Impacts...Unusually dry vegetation combined with gusty winds and low relative humidity will promote the potential for rapid fire spread with any fires that may start. Consult with local or state fire or forestry officials before burning. Remember that burn bans are in effect across Rutland, Windsor, Bennington, and Windham Counties. Never leave campfires unattended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Greens; Lower Connecticut Valley North

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued November 15 at 5:51PM EST until November 16 at 1:00AM EST by NWS Wakefield VA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 6 to 8 feet in the surf zone. For the Coastal Flood Warning, one to two feet of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways.
* WHERE...Eastern Currituck County.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 1 AM EST Saturday. For the Coastal Flood Warning, until 10 AM EST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Widespread flooding of vulnerable areas will result in an elevated threat of property damage to homes and businesses near the waterfront and shoreline. Water will be 1 to 2 feet above ground level in some areas resulting in a sufficient depth to close numerous roads and threaten homes and businesses. Flooding will extend inland from the waterfront along tidal rivers and bays resulting in some road closures and flooding of vehicles. Large breaking waves of 6 to 9 feet will result in dangerous surf conditions. Do not enter or approach the water due to the risk of being swept away.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Currituck

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 15 at 1:03PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A storm system is expected to enter the Chukchi Sea early next week. This will cause strong winds with gusts between 50 and 60 mph for the Northern Seward Peninsula and Northern Kotzebue Sound. These winds combined with the expected snowfall could result in near blizzard conditions at times.
In addition, localized ice shoves are a possibility with the new ice starting to form along the Northern Kotzebue Sound.
Stay up to date with the latest forecast by visiting our webpage, weather.gov/afg.
ST/JL/SL

entry.title: Child Abduction Emergency issued November 15 at 3:51PM CST by NWS Lake Charles LA
entry.summary:
CAELCH
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Texas Department of Public Safety.
THIS IS A STATEWIDE CHILD ABDUCTION ALERT ISSUED BY THE TEXAS AMBER ALERT NETWORK
The Henderson County Sheriffs Office is searching for missing child Mia James, eleven years old, White, Female, last seen wearing a long sleeved teal hoodie with the word venom in glitter and black shorts. The missing child was last seen at 8:25 PM, on November 14, 2024 at the 6200 Block of County Road 3925, Athens, TX 75752.
LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS BELIEVE THE CHILD TO BE IN GRAVE OR IMMEDIATE DANGER.
Anyone with information regarding this child abduction, should contact the Henderson County Sheriffs Office at 9 0 3 6 7 7 6 3 1 1.
News Media Point of Contact is Henderson County Sheriffs Office at 9 0 3 6 7 5 5 1 2 8.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Hardin, TX; Jasper, TX; Jefferson, TX; Newton, TX; Orange, TX; Tyler, TX

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued November 15 at 1:37PM PST until November 16 at 12:00PM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 5 to 8 feet are expected today and tonight, with local sets to 9 feet. High surf will slowly subside Saturday morning. There is a high risk of dangerous rip currents through Saturday.
* WHERE...Ventura County Beaches.
* WHEN...Until noon PST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk for ocean drowning. Rip currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large breaking waves can cause injury, wash people off beaches and rocks, and capsize small boats near shore.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...There may be some nuisance to minor coastal flooding on exposed west-facing beaches a couple of hours on either side of the high tide Saturday morning. High tide Saturday morning is around 830 AM PST.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ventura County Beaches

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued November 15 at 3:22PM EST until November 16 at 1:00PM EST by NWS Boston/Norton MA

* WHERE...Eastern Essex MA, Suffolk MA, Eastern Norfolk MA, Eastern Plymouth MA, Barnstable MA, Dukes MA and Nantucket MA Counties.
* WHEN...From 9 AM to 1 PM EST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Shallow pockets of flooding less than one foot deep affects the lowest lying areas along the coast, including Morrissey Boulevard in Boston. Most roads remain passable. entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 15 at 2:27PM EST by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
There is an increased risk for fire spread on Saturday for Delaware. Although minimum relative humidity values will be between 40 and 50 percent, conditions remain dry, and northwest winds will increase to 15 to 20 mph with 25 to 30 mph gusts on Saturday. These conditions could support the rapid spread of any fires that ignite, which could quickly become difficult to control.
Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged. Be sure to properly extinguish or dispose of any potential ignition sources, including smoking materials such as cigarette butts. Burn restrictions and burn bans are in effect for some areas. Refer to your state's forest fire management agency for more information on burn restrictions for your local area.
entry.cap:areaDesc: New Castle; Kent; Inland Sussex; Delaware Beaches

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued November 15 at 7:05AM PST until November 16 at 11:00AM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 12 to 15 ft with up to 18 ft along steep NW facing beaches.
* WHERE...Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern Monterey Bay and Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast.
* WHEN...Until 11 AM PST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Large waves can sweep across the beach without warning, pulling people into the sea from rocks, jetties and beaches. Sudden immersion in cold water can result in cold water shock even for the most experienced swimmers. Cold water shock can result in dramatic changes in breathing, heart rate and blood pressure, greatly increasing the risk of drowning in rough open waters.

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued November 15 at 7:05AM PST until November 16 at 11:00AM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, minor coastal flooding expected. For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 12 to 15 ft with up to 18 ft along steep NW facing beaches.
* WHERE...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, bayshore along the San Francisco Bay and San Pablo Bay. For the High Surf Advisory, all Pacific Coast beaches.
* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 4 PM PST Monday. San Francisco highest tides are Friday 6.95 ft at 10:04 am, Saturday 7.01 ft at 10:43 am, Sunday 6.89 ft at 11:26 am and Monday 6.60 ft at 12:11 pm. For the High Surf Advisory, until 11 AM PST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, flooding of lots, parks, and roads with only isolated road closures expected. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. For the High Surf Advisory, dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Large waves can sweep across the beach without warning, pulling people into the sea from rocks, jetties and beaches. Sudden immersion in cold water can result in cold water shock even for the most experienced swimmers. Cold water shock can result in dramatic changes in breathing, heart rate and blood pressure, greatly increasing the risk of drowning in rough open waters.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Francisco

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 15 at 4:39AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary: A slow moving storm system will bring periods of light to moderate snow to the Mat-Su Valleys Friday morning through Sunday morning. 3 to 6 inches of snow is possible for most locations, with the highest snow totals likely around Willow and Palmer. For locations in the Susitna Valley, the steadier snowfall is likely to fall this morning and again Saturday morning. For the Matanuska Valley, the steadier snow is likely to fall Saturday morning and again Sunday morning. The snow will taper off from west to east through Sunday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Matanuska Valley; Susitna Valley

entry.summary: A slow moving storm system will bring periods of light to moderate snow to the Western Kenai Peninsula Friday morning through Sunday morning. An additional 2 to 6 inches of snow is possible for most locations, with the highest snow totals likely in the Kenai and Soldotna areas. The snow will taper off from west to east, with snow showers possible along the higher terrain into Sunday morning.

entry.summary: A slow moving storm system will bring periods of light to moderate snow to the Anchorage Bowl Friday morning through Sunday morning. 3 to 6 inches of snow is possible for lower elevations of Anchorage with 5 to 10 inches possible for the Anchorage Hillside and Eagle River. The snow will taper off from west to east, with snow showers lingering along the Upper Hillside through Sunday morning.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued November 15 at 3:08AM HST until November 15 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING FOR LEEWARD AREAS OF ALL ISLANDS TODAY...
.The combination of dry fuels, low relative humidity and strong trade winds will bring critical fire weather conditions for leeward sections of the state today.
* AFFECTED AREA...Leeward portions of all Hawaiian Islands.
* TIMING...From 10 AM this morning to 6 PM HST this evening.
* WINDS...East 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 40 to 45 percent.
* IMPACTS...A combination of strong winds, low relative humidity, and dry fuels can contribute to extreme fire behavior. Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. A Red Flag Warning does not predict new fire starts.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued November 14 at 8:52AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has issued an Ozone High Pollution Advisory for the Yuma area on Friday.
This means that forecast weather conditions combined with existing ozone levels are expected to result in local maximum 8-hour ozone concentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates.
Ozone is an air contaminant which can cause breathing difficulties for children as well as persons with respiratory problems. A decrease in physical activity is recommended.
You are urged to car pool, telecommute or use mass transit. The use of gasoline-powered equipment should be reduced or done late in the day.
For details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet site at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/yuma or call 602-771-2300.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Yuma
